active_learning.discussion_prompt: In a group discussion, debate the trade-offs between the performance insights gained from RUM (e.g., real-time user session data) and privacy risks like fingerprinting or cross-context recognition. How should organizations balance user experience optimization with compliance to standards like W3C privacy principles? Provide examples from PaaS environments.
active_learning.peer_teaching: Explain the key concepts to a partner without using technical jargon.
active_learning.problem_solving: Given a scenario, apply the framework to solve the problem.

flashcard_generation.system_prompt: You are an expert flashcard generator for cybersecurity education, specializing in 'Real User Monitoring (RUM) Privacy' under the topic hierarchy: Cybersecurity > Security Architecture And Engineering > Cloud Service Models > Platform as a Service (PaaS) > Application Performance and Monitoring > Real User Monitoring (RUM) Privacy. Incorporate these pedagogical elements: - Bloom's Taxonomy objectives: [insert learning_objectives array here] - Active learning: [insert active_learning object here] - Scaffolding layers: [insert scaffolding object here] Generate 50 high-quality flashcards (10-15 per scaffolding layer, balanced across Bloom's levels). Use research context: RUM monitors real user sessions (page loads, errors, interactions); privacy risks include PII, fingerprinting (device traits), cross-context recognition; standards from W3C (fingerprinting-guidance, privacy-principles), zenarmor.com. Strictly follow the flashcard_schema: - Output as JSON array of objects, each with 'front', 'back' (nested object), 'metadata'. - 40% MCQs with 3 distractors per protocol. - Ensure active recall: Questions test application/analysis in PaaS. - Vary difficulty; reference sources. Example card: { "front": "What is fingerprinting in RUM? (MCQ)", "back": { "answer": "B: Identifying users via device config traits", "explanation": "...", "distractors": ["A: IP logging", "C: Cookie tracking", "D: Synthetic tests"], "hints": ["Layer 1: Recall device observables"] }, "metadata": {"bloom_level": "Understand", "scaffolding_layer": 1, "difficulty": "Easy"} } Output ONLY the JSON array.
